If the world is only 6,000 years old, and the concentration of oxygen in ice cores 6,000 years ago is about the same as today (20%) how do creationists explain how giant arthropods such as Meganeura monyi, Arthropleura and Mesothelae lived or moved with such a low oxygen content?
 
 Evolution however argues that such organisms were able to grow to such large proportions due to the late carboniferous having a 36% oxygen content, thus fueling such massive arthropod growth.

 Here's a link that pretty much nullifies childs claims and attributes CO2 with the reason for increased growth due to abundant plant life and perfect tropical conditions. Not to mention that even today, reptiles, which dinos are, grow for their complete lives. So although there was a slightly higher oxygen level, it wasn't the reason for larger growth of reptiles.
 The article relates the prolific plant growth to the huge size of the herbivorous (plant eating) dinosaurs of the Cretaceous and the carnivorous beasts who preyed on them. It makes sense.
 
 What intriques me however, is what caused these very high levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide? Estimates are as great as 500% greater than they are today? (As much as 2000 ppm (parts per million) versus today's approximate 350 ppm.) Some say this was caused by increased volcanic activity. I don't think so.
 
 It is well known that as water warms, its ability to hold dissolved CO2 decreases. Since the world's oceans contain approximately 97% of all the CO2 on Earth, any warming of the oceans would release great amounts of CO2 into the atmosphere. This would of course increase plant growth, enable dinosaurs to grow to enormous sizes, and create these extremely thick coal beds.
 
 What caused the warming? It sure wasn't man's burning of fossil fuels over one hundred million years ago. The warming was probably primarily caused by changes in solar activity. Later, the climate cooled, the oceans absorbed more CO2, limiting plant growth, starving the dinosaurs, and ending the massive deposition of plant material making up the thick coal beds. This is a simplified summary, but the idea is supported by geologic evidence from all around the world. This is a "working hypothesis". What do you think?
 http://petesplace-peter.blogspot.com/2008/01/how-dinosaurs-got-so-bigwarming-in.html

 That is extremely embarrassing Angel. What you posted has nothing to do with oxygen utilization in biological growth. Furthermore, you thinking that it does shows a massive incompetence in understanding basic biology of non-photosynthetic carbon based organisms. Co2 does not carry oxygen within the veins or trachea. Oxygen is required for operation of organs. I thought you were ignorant, but this takes the cake. O2 is required in the breakdown of stored sugar that is used in metabolism. Co2 is not. Larger organisms require more O2. Some of the largest organisms on the planet today have pathways that weight massive amounts, the blue whale's veins are extremely heavy. But insects don't have veins and their trachea function through oxygen naturally through ventilation or simple diffusion. They lack the ability to transfer large amounts of diffused oxygen through their bodies. That's what keeps them small: they can't get enough oxygen to fuel larger bodies. Your article has nothing to do with increased oxygen utilization in arthropods. Even more embarrassing for you is that the blog's author is making the point that more Co2 results in more vegetation resulting in larger amounts of food for dinosaurs resulting in larger sizes. Again, where did you see Oxygen in that blog? Or do you not understand the difference between Co2 and O2?
 
 This should tell you that maybe you should know something about the subject before opening your mouth.

 Quite simple. You posted a link that said that increased Co2 levels were responsible for large growth in arthropods. It's obvious that larger bodies require more ATP. But without a method of vastly increasing access to O2, there is no way of producing that on a sustainable level, especially for something that has a wing span of over 2 meters and that has a respiratory system that runs on diffusion. Without increased Krebs Cycle activity, there is no additional ATP production. In organisms that rely on diffusion, with a massive increase on oxygen to fuel the Krebs Cycle, they can't produce more ATP. Without more ATP, their bodies can't grow larger.
 
 You keep failing to understand very basics of biology respiration and thus why your argument is fantastically stupid.
